columns.text: This exercise requires us to explain the reason why all firms do not increase their payables periods to shorten their cash cycles.
Increasing the payable period is not suitable for some firms because of different circumstances. In addition, the extension of the payable period may result in a loss of key suppliers.

In BlueSky's case, an extension of 30 to 45 days in the payment of invoices can harm their small suppliers who do not have enough financial depth to weather the extension. Another reason is that it distorts the company's financial accounts and has a detrimental impact on cash flow.
For this question, we are going to examine the topic of why not all companies grow their payables.

In this case, we will explain why owners of businesses do not include functionality concerning the lengths of payment periods in order to considerably minimize the number of times working capital is iterated. Those who have secret desires to Even though the account payable period represents a component of the total cost of production that goes toward paying a company's suppliers, it is an issue that generates a lot of discussion. In reality, a company will try to get to a point where the amount of time it takes to pay its bills is proportional to the amount of money it makes.

As a consequence of this, the company would have a considerably more difficult time obtaining financing and would become less motivated to keep its operational procedures running smoothly. Because of this, it is preferable for a firm to have a short amount of time to collect money rather than a lengthy amount of time to convert money back into cash.
